experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ll be honest, I’m kinda stressed—I have a big presentation coming up in my algorithms class, and just thinking about it makes my palms sweat.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally normal to feel that way before a presentation—even with low social anxiety, big classes can be intimidating. Try practicing in front of a small group of friends first to build confidence. Break your talk into sections and focus on mastering one part at a time. You've got the smarts; now it's about sharing them comfortably. You'll do great!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess practicing with a few people from my study group could be okay. It's just hard not to think about how one bad presentation could mess up my whole GPA and grad school chances.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—grad school pressure is real! But remember, one presentation won't define your entire academic journey. Professors usually weigh assignments, and showing improvement matters too. Focus on delivering your content clearly rather than perfection. You've come this far because of your hard work; trust that resilience. You got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it's just hard not to feel like every single assignment is a huge part of my final transcript for grad school applications. I'll try to just focus on getting through it clearly.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly—clarity over perfection is a great mindset. Grad schools look at growth and overall trends, not just one assignment. You're building skills that matter beyond grades, like resilience and communication. Keep that perspective, take a deep breath, and tackle it one step at a time. You're capable!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, it's just hard to believe it sometimes when I'm staring at a bad grade. I'll try to just focus on the next assignment instead of the whole GPA.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the spirit! Progress over perfection—every assignment is a chance to learn and improve. Reflect briefly on feedback, then channel that energy into your next task. You're building skills that matter more than any single grade. Keep moving forward; you're doing better than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess you're right... it's just hard not to obsess over a bad grade when grad school applications are so competitive. I'll try to focus on the next coding assignment instead.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! Channel that energy into your coding project—it's a tangible way to build skills and confidence. Remember, grad schools value growth and persistence, not just flawless transcripts. You're taking proactive steps, and that resilience will shine through. Keep coding and believing in your progress!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I just worry that my project isn't impressive enough compared to what other applicants will have. But I'll keep working on it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Your project doesn't need to be groundbreaking—it needs to show your passion and problem-solving skills. Focus on clear documentation, clean code, and explaining your process thoughtfully. That's what impresses admissions committees. You're on the right track—keep building and refining!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but I just keep worrying my code isn't innovative enough to stand out for grad school applications. I'll try to focus on making the documentation really clear, I guess.

improvement_areas: Improve i stay calm when dealing with problems.
Continue practicing social skills through regular interaction
Focus on emotional regulation and conflict resolution

responses.question: I ask for help when I need it.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 1. [Rating: 3/4] I'm pretty good about asking for help with coding problems or classwork, but I tend to hesitate when it comes to asking for help with bigger things like my student loans or finding a ...

responses.question: I stay calm when dealing with problems.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 2. [Rating: 2/4] I can handle technical problems logically, but my neuroticism means I can get pretty stressed about financial or personal challenges before I calm down enough to deal with them....

responses.question: I help my friends when they are having a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 3. [Rating: 4/4] I'm always there for my friends. If they're having a problem, especially with a project or tech issue, I'll drop what I'm doing to help....

responses.question: I work well with my classmates.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 4. [Rating: 4/4] Group projects are usually great. I'm extraverted and enjoy collaborating, and I'm good at dividing up coding tasks based on everyone's strengths....

responses.question: I do the right thing without being told.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 5. [Rating: 3/4] For the most part, yes. I'll start studying for an exam without being reminded, but I'm not always as proactive as I should be with things like budgeting....

responses.question: I do my part in a group.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 6. [Rating: 4/4] Absolutely. I hate the idea of being the person who doesn't pull their weight. I always make sure my part of the work is done and done well....

responses.question: I stay calm when I disagree with others.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 7. [Rating: 3/4] I'm open to different ideas, so I can usually stay calm. But if it's about a technical approach I'm passionate about, I might get a little too intense in my explanation....

responses.question: I stand up for others when they are not treated well.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 8. [Rating: 4/4] I can't stand seeing someone get treated unfairly, especially in a team setting. I'll definitely speak up, even if it's a little uncomfortable....

responses.question: I look at people when I talk to them.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 9. [Rating: 3/4] I do, but sometimes when I'm trying to explain a complex concept, I might look away at my screen or my notes while I'm thinking....

responses.question: I am careful when I use things that aren't mine.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 10. [Rating: 4/4] I'm super careful, especially with other people's tech. I know how expensive it is and how much of a pain it is to have your stuff broken....

responses.question: I let people know when there's a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 11. [Rating: 3/4] I'll point out a bug in the code or a logic error in a plan immediately. I'm less quick to bring up interpersonal issues or my own financial worries....

responses.question: I pay attention when the teacher talks to the class.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 12. [Rating: 3/4] I pay attention, but my mind can wander to a problem I'm trying to solve in my own code. I'm engaged, but not always 100% focused....

responses.question: I try to make others feel better.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 13. [Rating: 4/4] I really try to be encouraging. If a friend is stressed about an exam or a project, I'll try to hype them up or offer to study together....

responses.question: I say "thank you" when someone helps me.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 14. [Rating: 4/4] Always. It's just basic decency, and I genuinely appreciate it when people take time to help me out....

responses.question: I keep my promises.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 15. [Rating: 4/4] If I say I'm going to do something, I do it. My word is important to me, whether it's meeting a project deadline or showing up to hang out....

responses.question: I pay attention when others present their ideas.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 16. [Rating: 4/4] I'm genuinely interested in other people's ideas, especially creative solutions to CS problems. I love a good brainstorming session....

responses.question: I try to find a good way to end a disagreement.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 17. [Rating: 3/4] I'm good at finding a technical compromise, like merging two pieces of code. For more personal disagreements, I'm still learning the best approach....

responses.question: I try to think about how others feel.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 18. [Rating: 3/4] I try, but I'll admit I can be a bit wrapped up in my own stress about loans and grades. It's something I have to consciously remind myself to do....

responses.question: I try to forgive others when they say "sorry".
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 19. [Rating: 4/4] Definitely. I believe people deserve a second chance, and if someone is genuinely sorry, there's no point in holding a grudge....

responses.question: I follow school rules.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 20. [Rating: 4...
